Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Singapore
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Kevin Yehl of Emory University to conduct a research project in Biology during the summer of 2013 at National University of Singapore in Singapore. The project title is "Correcting Gene Errors by Using a Nanoparticle Therapy." The host scientist is Dr. Xiaogang Liu.

Nature's ability to selectively edit the genome by cleaving and ligating portions of messenger RNA (mRNA) is a process termed splicing and enables a single gene to encode for a diverse set of proteins. This processes increases the diversity of living systems and is responsible for why complex organisms, such as humans, can display vast collection of proteins using such a relatively small number of genes. Although this process is highly regulated, it remains error prone, and can result in specific types of diseases. This research project addresses this problem by rationally designing a synthetic spliceosome, a nano-spliceozyme, through spatially confining the appropriate catalytic units on a nanoparticle scaffold, which can edit these problematic gene products (mRNA). If successful, the project may lead to novel therapeutics to treat cancers and undruggable genetic diseases.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. This experience will initiate future collaborations between the two labs and also establish future collaborative contacts for the Fellow. In addition, the Fellow intends to construct a blog, which will be posted at the home university's chemistry department website and will be updated bi-weekly during the summer collaboration. Moreover, the Fellow will construct a publically accessible webpage describing in general terms the research studied and pictures documenting the summer experience and Singapore culture. Prior to departure, the fellow mentored Emory undergraduates in preparing the necessary enzyme for the research project. Also, the Fellow will give a presentation to the home chemistry department describing the experience. In order to impact the local community, the Fellow will work with Emory's center for science education to incorporate their scientific discoveries into local high school and college curriculums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the NSF supported EAPSI fellowship, I investigated enzymatically powered nanomaterials in Xiaogang Liu's lab at the National University of Singapore. Nanomaterials have gained much interest recently because of the unique electronic, optical, and mechanical properties they possess because of their size, shape and composition. Due to these properties, nanomaterials have potential to revolutionize many fields ranging from energy to bio-medical.

For this collaboration, I focused on developing nanomaterials as a bio-medical diagnostic tool to distinguish between cancerous and healthy cells. Previously, nanomaterials with the unique optical property to glow when irradiated by a laser source were designed to selectively bind to the surface of cancerous cells and be taken up. This material would allow the surgeon to visibly see the cancerous cells while performing surgery, which it is normally difficult to distinguish cancerous cells from healthy cells. Fully removing the cancerous cells is important so that the cancer does not return. However, since the nanomaterial needs to be excited (powered) by a laser light source, only cells close to the surface can be imaged, where cells a few millimeters below the surface cannot be seen. In addition, due to requiring a laser source, scattering of laser light is observed and makes it difficult to distinguish cancerous cells.

To overcome these limitations, we aimed to design a non-toxic nanomaterial that could be enzymatically powered rather than laser powered (Scheme 1). The goal was to modify the surface of a nanoparticle with the enzyme luciferase, which is the enzyme responsible for the glow observed in lightning bugs. The light energy produced by the enzyme was expected to be transferred to the nanomaterial and glow without the need of laser excitation. The project goals were to study this phenomenon and measure the rate and amount of energy transfer from enzyme to the particle.

Over the 8 week collaboration, I characterized the rate and amount of light the enzyme could produce alone (Figure 1). Next, I synthesized and characterized the optical properties of many types of lanthanide doped nanoparticles ~20nm in diameter by varying the particle composition. The particle composition was variried to change the wavelength of light the particle glowed when excited. Lastly, the particle surface was modified with the enzyme to study the rate and amount of energy transferred. However, we discovered that under the current conditions to modify the surface of the particle, the enzyme was inhibited, so that it could not produce the light energy necessary to excite the particle. This project is on going. In addition to the technical progress of this project, the EAPSI fellowship initiated a valuable collaboration between Emory University and the National University of Singapore.
